content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose R{R}. Here's my reasoning:

In this game, it seems that choosing R is slightly advantageous over choosing B when playing against an unknown opponent, as you get 5$ more when they pick R (45$ compared to 40$). However, if we assume that the anonymous player is rational and wants to maximize their earnings like me, then it's less likely that they would stick with one choice for all 75 rounds because it would lead to a lower payoff in some rounds.

Ideally, an optimal strategy for an anonymous player would be to switch between R and B after each round based on the previous outcome. If they picked R last round and got 0$, then they'd pick B next round, and if they picked B last round and got 35$, then they'd pick R next round. This way, they'd get the maximum payoff in every other round (40$) and a slightly lower but still decent payoff (35$) in the remaining rounds.

However, as a human player, I can't predict what my anonymous opponent will do with absolute certainty. If I choose R consistently, there is still a chance that my opponent switches strategies mid-game, causing me to get 40$ for some rounds instead of 45$. But if I stick with R, even though the payoff might not be optimal in every round, it gives me a better average outcome over 75 rounds compared to choosing B consistently.

In conclusion, while both strategies have their flaws, choosing R seems like a more stable and reasonable choice as a human player, despite potentially getting 40$ instead of 45$ in some rounds. However, if the game is repeated many times with different opponents or under different conditions, my optimal strategy might change based on the information available about the players I'm facing.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I chose R, and my opponent also chose R. Since we both picked R, our payoffs are both 45$.

For the next round, I will still choose R{R}. The reasoning behind this is that my previous choice of R worked out well in this case since my opponent also chose R. As a human player, it's hard to predict how my opponent will switch their strategy after each round, so sticking with R gives me the opportunity to get 45$ again if my opponent decides to stick with R as well.

If I were to switch my choice to B, there's a chance that my opponent might have switched to B as well because of our previous outcome. In that case, I would only receive 35$, which is 10$ less than what I got in the previous round when we both chose R.

However, if my opponent decides to switch back to R after this round, I would get 40$ instead of 45$. The key point here is that switching strategies might result in a lower average payoff over multiple rounds compared to sticking with R and taking advantage of the opportunity when my opponent also chooses R.

In other words, since we both chose R in the previous round, there's still a chance that my opponent will stick with R again for the next round, giving me an opportunity to maximize my earnings. Therefore, I will choose R{R} for the next round.
